unit_title: LC Circuits: Oscillations in Inductor-Capacitor Circuits
subject: AP Physics C: Electricity & Magnetism
expanded_description: This unit explores LC circuits, which exhibit pure harmonic oscillations through continuous energy exchange between electric fields in capacitors and magnetic fields in inductors. Students will learn to analyze these ideal oscillators mathematically, understand the phase relationships between current and voltage, and explore both ideal and practical LC circuit behavior.
learning_objectives: Derive and solve the differential equation for ideal LC circuits
Calculate natural frequency and period of LC oscillations
Analyze energy exchange between capacitor and inductor
Determine initial conditions and their effect on oscillations
Analyze RLC circuits with small resistance
Apply LC circuit principles to practical oscillator design
prerequisites: Knowledge of simple harmonic motion mathematics
Familiarity with complex numbers and phasors

core_concept.principle: LC Oscillations, Energy Exchange, Harmonic Motion, Natural Frequency
core_concept.explanation: LC circuits exhibit ideal harmonic oscillations where energy continuously transfers between the capacitor's electric field and the inductor's magnetic field. This represents an electromagnetic analog of mechanical spring-mass systems, with the natural frequency determined solely by the values of L and C.

image.caption: Continuous energy exchange in LC oscillator circuits

sections.section_title: 1. Ideal LC Circuit Analysis and Oscillations
sections.introduction: This section establishes the mathematical foundation for ideal LC circuits, deriving the governing differential equations and analyzing the pure harmonic oscillations that result from continuous energy exchange between electric and magnetic fields.

key_concept.definition: LC Oscillations, Second-Order Differential Equations, Natural Frequency, Energy Conservation
key_concept.context: Ideal LC circuits with no resistance exhibit perfect, undamped oscillations where the total energy remains constant while continuously exchanging between capacitive (electric field) and inductive (magnetic field) storage. This represents one of the few ideal harmonic oscillators in electrical engineering.

image.caption: Mathematical analysis of ideal LC circuit oscillations

classifications.type: LC Circuit Configurations and Initial Conditions
classifications.value: Classification by circuit topology and starting state
characteristics: Charged capacitor initial condition: maximum voltage start
Current initial condition: maximum current start
classifications.behavior: Different configurations and initial conditions produce characteristic oscillation patterns. Series LC shows current oscillations. Charged capacitor start produces cosine voltage. Current initial condition produces sine current. Combined conditions give phase shifts. Parallel LC has dual behavior. Multiple elements create beat frequencies.

classifications.note: The natural angular frequency ω₀ = 1/√(LC) is determined solely by the circuit parameters L and C, independent of initial conditions or oscillation amplitude

principles.statement: Governing Equation: L(d²q/dt²) + q/C = 0 or d²q/dt² + (1/LC)q = 0. Natural Frequency: ω₀ = 1/√(LC), f₀ = 1/(2π√(LC)), T = 2π√(LC). General Solution: q(t) = Q_max cos(ω₀t + φ), I(t) = -ω₀Q_max sin(ω₀t + φ). Energy Relations: U_total = ½Q_max²/C = ½LI_max². Energy Exchange: U_C = ½q²/C, U_L = ½LI². Phase Relationships: Voltage leads current by 90° in capacitor, current leads voltage by 90° in inductor. Initial Conditions: Determine amplitude and phase. Charged Capacitor: q(0)=Q₀, I(0)=0 → q(t)=Q₀cos(ω₀t). Initial Current: q(0)=0, I(0)=I₀ → q(t)=(I₀/ω₀)sin(ω₀t). Applications: Tank circuits in radios. Frequency generators. Signal filters. Energy storage systems. Electronic oscillators. Resonance systems.
principles.application: Solve the LC circuit differential equation. Calculate natural frequency and period. Determine oscillation amplitudes from initial conditions. Analyze energy exchange during oscillations. Design LC circuits for specific frequencies. Predict current and voltage waveforms.
principles.example: LC circuit with L=1mH, C=1μF: ω₀=1/√(10⁻³×10⁻⁶)=31623 rad/s, f₀=5033 Hz, T=199 μs. For Q_max=10μC: I_max=ω₀Q_max=0.316 A, U_total=50 μJ.
principles.analogy: An LC circuit is like a 'electromagnetic swing'—the capacitor is the 'height' (voltage) and the inductor is the 'motion' (current). When the swing is at its highest point (max capacitor voltage), it's momentarily still (zero current). When it's moving fastest through the bottom (max inductor current), it's at its lowest point (zero voltage). The energy constantly converts between 'height energy' (electric field) and 'motion energy' (magnetic field), just like a perfect swing with no friction. The natural frequency is like the 'swing's natural rhythm'—determined only by the 'rope length' (LC values), not by how hard you push. Initial conditions are like 'how you start the swing'—from rest at some height, or with a push from the bottom.

worked_examples.title: Ideal LC Circuit with Charged Capacitor
worked_examples.problem: An LC circuit has L=2mH, C=0.5μF. The capacitor is initially charged to 12V. Find: (a) natural frequency and period, (b) maximum current, (c) expressions for q(t) and I(t), (d) times when capacitor energy equals inductor energy.

step_by_step.explanation: q(t) = Q_max cos(ω₀t) = 6×10⁻⁶ cos(31,623t) C, I(t) = -ω₀Q_max sin(ω₀t) = -0.1897 sin(31,623t) A
U_C = U_L when ½q²/C = ½LI². Since total energy conserved, this occurs when each has half total energy: U_C = ½U_total → ½q²/C = ½(½Q_max²/C) → q² = Q_max²/2 → q = ±Q_max/√2

worked_examples.title: LC Circuit with Initial Current
worked_examples.problem: An LC circuit with L=0.1H, C=10μF has initial current I₀=0.5A and initial charge q₀=0. Find: (a) natural frequency, (b) maximum capacitor voltage, (c) expressions for q(t) and I(t).

step_by_step.step: Find maximum charge from energy conservation
step_by_step.explanation: Initial energy: U₀ = ½LI₀² = ½×0.1×(0.5)² = 0.0125 J. At max charge, U = ½Q_max²/C → Q_max = √(2CU₀) = √(2×10×10⁻⁶×0.0125) = √(2.5×10⁻⁷) = 5×10⁻⁴ C = 500 μC
q(t) = Q_max cos(ω₀t + φ), I(t) = -ω₀Q_max sin(ω₀t + φ). q(0)=Q_max cosφ=0 → φ=±π/2. I(0)=-ω₀Q_max sinφ=0.5 → sinφ negative → φ=-π/2
q(t) = Q_max cos(ω₀t - π/2) = Q_max sin(ω₀t) = 500 sin(1000t) μC, I(t) = -ω₀Q_max sin(ω₀t - π/2) = ω₀Q_max cos(ω₀t) = 0.5 cos(1000t) A
q(0)=0, I(0)=0.5 A, matches given conditions

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) f₀=159.2 Hz. (b) V_max=50 V. (c) q(t)=500sin(1000t) μC, I(t)=0.5cos(1000t) A. Circuit oscillates with current leading voltage by 90°.

worked_examples.title: Energy Analysis in LC Oscillations
worked_examples.problem: For an LC circuit with L=4mH, C=0.25μF, and Q_max=8μC, plot the energies U_C, U_L, and U_total over one complete cycle and verify energy conservation.

step_by_step.explanation: q(t) = 8cos(ω₀t) μC, I(t) = -0.253sin(ω₀t) A, U_C(t) = ½q²/C = ½×(64×10⁻¹² cos²(ω₀t))/(0.25×10⁻⁶) = 128 cos²(ω₀t) μJ, U_L(t) = ½LI² = ½×4×10⁻³×(0.064 sin²(ω₀t)) = 128 sin²(ω₀t) μJ
U_total = U_C + U_L = 128(cos²(ω₀t) + sin²(ω₀t)) = 128 μJ, constant
At t=0: U_C=128 μJ, U_L=0. At t=T/4: U_C=0, U_L=128 μJ. At t=T/2: U_C=128 μJ, U_L=0. Complete energy exchange every quarter cycle.
Energies equal when cos²(ω₀t)=sin²(ω₀t) → ω₀t=π/4, 3π/4, 5π/4, 7π/4 → t=T/8, 3T/8, 5T/8, 7T/8

worked_examples.final_answer: U_C(t)=128cos²(31,623t) μJ, U_L(t)=128sin²(31,623t) μJ, U_total=128 μJ constant. Energy completely exchanges between capacitor and inductor four times per cycle, with equal energies at t=T/8, 3T/8, 5T/8, 7T/8.

sections.introduction: This section extends the ideal LC circuit analysis to practical scenarios including resistance effects, driven oscillations, and real-world applications in electronics, communications, and energy systems.

key_concept.definition: RLC Circuits, Damped Oscillations, Resonance, Quality Factor, Practical Applications
key_concept.context: Real LC circuits always include some resistance, leading to damped oscillations. Understanding these practical circuits requires analyzing the RLC differential equation and introducing concepts like quality factor and bandwidth. These practical oscillators form the basis for numerous electronic applications including filters, oscillators, and tuned circuits.

image.caption: Analysis of practical RLC circuits and applications

characteristics: Driven RLC: forced oscillations at resonance
Coupled LC circuits: energy transfer systems
classifications.behavior: Different damping conditions produce characteristic responses. Underdamped circuits exhibit decaying oscillations. Critical damping provides fastest settling. Overdamped circuits decay slowly. Driven circuits show resonance peaks. Coupled circuits exchange energy. Nonlinear circuits have complex dynamics.

classifications.note: The quality factor Q = ω₀L/R = 1/(ω₀CR) = (1/R)√(L/C) quantifies the damping in RLC circuits, with high Q (>½) indicating underdamped oscillatory behavior

principles.statement: RLC Equation: L(d²q/dt²) + R(dq/dt) + q/C = 0. Characteristic Equation: Ls² + Rs + 1/C = 0. Damping Types: Underdamped: R² < 4L/C, ω_d = √(ω₀² - α²) where α=R/(2L). Critically damped: R² = 4L/C. Overdamped: R² > 4L/C. Quality Factor: Q = ω₀L/R = (1/R)√(L/C). Damping Ratio: ζ = R/(2√(L/C)) = 1/(2Q). Bandwidth: Δω = ω₀/Q for driven circuits. Resonance: Maximum response when driving frequency = ω₀. Applications: Radio tuners and filters. Oscillator circuits. Signal generators. Impedance matching networks. Waveform shaping circuits. Energy storage systems.
principles.application: Analyze damping in RLC circuits. Calculate quality factor and bandwidth. Design circuits for specific damping characteristics. Analyze resonance in driven RLC circuits. Design practical oscillators and filters. Apply LC circuits to communication systems.
principles.example: RLC with L=1mH, C=1μF, R=10Ω: ω₀=31,623 rad/s, α=5,000, ω_d=31,224 rad/s, Q=3.16, underdamped oscillations. Critical damping when R=63.2Ω.
principles.analogy: Practical RLC circuits are like 'swings with friction'—the resistance is the 'air resistance' that slowly steals energy, making the oscillations die out. The quality factor Q is like how many 'swings' you get before the motion becomes small—high Q means many oscillations (good resonator), low Q means quick stopping (good damper). Resonance is like 'pushing a swing in rhythm'—when you push at exactly the natural frequency, even small pushes build up large motions. Bandwidth is like how 'picky' the swing is about pushing rhythm—high Q (narrow bandwidth) means it only responds to exactly the right rhythm, while low Q (wide bandwidth) responds to a range of rhythms. LC tanks in radios are like 'rhythm detectors' that only 'listen' to stations broadcasting at their specific natural frequency.

worked_examples.title: Energy Loss in Practical LC Circuit
worked_examples.problem: An LC circuit with L=5mH, C=200pF, R=2Ω oscillates with initial energy 100μJ. Calculate: (a) oscillation frequency, (b) quality factor, (c) energy after 100 cycles, (d) time for energy to decay to 1% of initial.

step_by_step.explanation: Fraction of energy lost per cycle ≈ 2π/Q = 2π/2500 = 0.002513
Number of cycles in 23 ms = 0.023/6.283×10⁻⁶ = 3,662 cycles. Energy after N cycles ≈ e^(-2πN/Q) = e^(-2π×3662/2500) = e^(-9.21) = 0.0001 = 0.01%, close to 1%

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) f₀=159.2 kHz. (b) Q=2,500. (c) Energy after 100 cycles=77.7 μJ. (d) Time to 1% energy=23.0 ms. High Q gives very slow energy decay.

common_misconceptions: Thinking LC oscillations require continuous energy input
Believing resistance only affects oscillation frequency
Confusing quality factor with quality of components
Thinking critically damped means no response
Believing LC circuits can oscillate at any frequency
Assuming all oscillators need transistors or active elements
Thinking damping only affects amplitude, not frequency
summary: This unit has comprehensively explored LC circuits from ideal harmonic oscillators to practical RLC systems with damping. Students have learned to analyze the continuous energy exchange between electric and magnetic fields, calculate natural frequencies and damping characteristics, and apply these concepts to real-world applications in communications, power electronics, and signal processing. Understanding LC oscillations provides fundamental insight into resonant systems and forms the basis for designing frequency-selective circuits essential in modern electronics.
